explanation: OS_object_token_t: Needed to know whether obj_id/obj_idx/obj_type are members of the token object (i.e., the code modifies the pointed-to object) and to confirm whether the function parameter is a pointer type (OS_object_token_t *). This determines whether the code is only modifying the pointee (allowed) or the pointer itself (disallowed). OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to access the object table with '*token'. The macro definition can include side-effects (e.g., modify the token variable or its fields, or call other helpers). Inspecting it is required to ensure no assignment to the token parameter itself occurs. OS_common_record_t: Definition of the record type returned by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; needed to confirm that record->active_id access is a modification of a separate object and not an alias that could affect the token pointer variable. OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t: The typedef/signature of the MatchFunc callback. Its parameter list (whether it takes OS_object_token_t * or OS_object_token_t **, etc.) determines whether the call MatchFunc(arg, token, record) could legally modify the token pointer variable in the caller. OS_ObjectIdDefined: The definition (function or macro) is used in the conditional; if it is a macro it could have side-effects that modify the token or token-> fields. Confirming it does not modify the parameter is necessary. OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Often used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET implementations to convert a token to an index; include it because the macro may invoke it and it may have side-effects touching the token/pointer. OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED: The constant assigned to token->obj_id; its definition (macro/enum) is needed to ensure that assignment targets the pointee member, not some macro that hides an assignment to the pointer parameter itself.
